title: Testing out the closeread extension!
text:
require("https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/npm/juxtaposejs@1.1.6/build/js/juxtapose.min.js")
  .catch(() => null)







Basic tests
Below is my first practice with trying out closeread, hopefully it gives us an idea of what we can do with.




Closeread enables scrollytelling.




Draw your readers attention with focus effects.




an easy use of this is to display text next to an image (like this random photo pulled from unsplash!):




this might be useful to show change over time:
For example, here is the graph we have of annual average PM2.5 air pollution in Ethiopia in 1998â€¦




compared with air pollution in 2022! Look at the difference!




we can even zoom in to look at some of our communitiesâ€¦ for example around Addis Ababa:




or even look at the difference across our communities by panning up towards Tigray!







Highlighting
Zooming
Panning




Image by Amber Kipp on Unsplash










I can split up sections of scrollytelling using normal text, figures, tables and graphs:
Duis urna urna, pellentesque eu urna ut, malesuada bibendum dolor. Suspendisse potenti. Vivamus ornare, arcu quis molestie ultrices, magna est accumsan augue, auctor vulputate erat quam quis neque. Nullam scelerisque odio vel ultricies facilisis. Ut porta arcu non magna sagittis lacinia. Cras ornare vulputate lectus a tristique. Pellentesque ac arcu congue, rhoncus mi id, dignissim ligula.


Juxtaposing images
I have even tried out using a bit of Javascript to give a juxtapose of 2 images, which lets you use the slider to compare across time, give it a try below!




Hopefully it works! Testing it a bit however it seems the juxtapose.js doesnâ€™t work inside the scrollytelling sectionsâ€¦ðŸ˜­




The text can be moved around, we can set it to layout on the right side of the sticky item















Or we can have it overlay the image/item, aligned to the right















Or over the top of the itemâ€¦











So far I have used images that are pre-rendered, but as I am typing this using Quarto markdown in R, I can display the output of code executed in R (and python, Julia, Observable, etc)




Here is a simple graph made using this code:

hist(rnorm(15))





they can even be interactive!

Step 2: Importing the module
Letâ€™s try it out. JuxtaposeJS is on jsDelivr, so we can just import it! Itâ€™s a little stubborn, but requiring the individual file, rather than just the package name, seems to work (thanks, Observable Module Require Debugger!). It produces an error but seems to work, so I just catch the error and ignore it:

require("https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/npm/juxtaposejs@1.1.6/build/js/juxtapose.min.js")
  .catch(() => null)
